page.title: 03LAUGHARNE, TOWN AND AROUND
page.content: The present appearance of Laugharne stems from the 18th and 19th Centuries but its Church and Castle at each end of the main street denote 13th Century origins. Laugharne has two areas - 'up-street' being the area between the Church and Castle House with most of the best buildings, and 'down-street', focussed on a once busy port with cottages and merchants houses around the site of the Quay and warehouses. Laugharne was designated an Outstanding Conservation Area (1971) due to its Castle and precincts, ancient street plan, waterfront, and Georgian/Regency houses. Besides good views from the hills, the estuary, the Strand plus fine buildings, the town also has eyesores which depress the overall standard of the Township.
